sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A show of unity in Kiev as German Chancellor Olaf Scholz holds talks with President Zelensky warning that the territorial integrity of Ukraine is not negotiable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov urges Vladimir Putin to allow more time for diplomacy as the President signs off on Russia's response to the West on security guarantees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, a number of European Union countries say they are preparing for an influx of Ukrainian refugees in the event of a conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And cleared to compete but not of doping.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Russia's Kamila Valieva gets the green light to take to the ice once again at the Winter Games.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Good to have you with us. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz has urged Russia

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: to use dialogue in order to resolve its current tensions with Ukraine. The Chancellor's comments came after a meeting with Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Kiev. Scholz will be flying to Moscow on Tuesday for talks with President Vladimir Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Germany has been stepping up its diplomatic and security efforts as fears of a Russian invasion of Ukraine grow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Berlin has deployed more NATO troops to Lithuania and has pledged over 2 billion euros of economic aid to Kiev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: With more than 2 billion dollars, we have made the Ukrainian economy more resilient and independent. In the face of foreign influence, we have ensured its autonomy and resilience.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And I can assure you that we will continue this support with the same determination.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: However, Ukraine's leader was keen to bring up Germany's energy dealings with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: President Zelensky called the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline a geopolitical weapon against Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: I emphasize that our position remains the same.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We consider Nord Stream 2 solely through the prism of energy and security threats to us and the region. We clearly understand that this is a geopolitical weapon. That's why Ukraine needs energy security guarantees. Let's go straight to Kiev then, where Sasha Vakulina is standing by. Welcome to you, Sasha. To begin with, we know that Chancellor Scholz said earlier, it's a quote here, if Russia again violates the territorial integrity of Ukraine, we will know what to do.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Is it clear what will happen?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, Helena, it's not as clear as many hoped it would be. He really did not give much details on that, only saying that there is a package of sanctions that has been worked on and the decision to implement that package can be made any moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He also said that he will tell Vladimir Putin that any invasion would have heavy economic consequences.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, of course, the question here, would those consequences include anything regarding the Nord Stream 2 pipeline?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That we do not know. Without naming this project, he said, though, that no one should doubt the determination and preparedness of Berlin to punish Russia in case of attacks and invasion. Meanwhile, we've also been hearing from the Ukrainian foreign minister speaking to his U.S. counterpart, Secretary of State Antony Blinken, about sending an OSCE mission to the east of Ukraine to monitor the separatist conflict there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: What more do we know about that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The special monitoring mission of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe have been in the east of Ukraine for years now, monitoring and taking record of everything that's been happening there of all the developments now of course in the past few days we've heard the calls from the US and other countries where they're urging their citizens to leave Ukraine immediately saying go now as long as it's still possible to leave Ukraine and of course there are some reports that some of the always Organization for Security and and cooperation members are withdrawing from the east of Ukraine and leaving the country and this was of course of a great concern for Ukraine's foreign minister for Ukrainian authorities and there was the conversation that happened today when Dmytro Kuleba said that it is very important to keep that mission going. All right, Sasha Vakulina in Kiev. Sasha, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In Moscow, Russia's President Vladimir Putin held security meetings with his defence and foreign ministers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Following the Kremlin's request for security guarantees from NATO, the President asked for an update on diplomatic negotiations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: Now, although the US and NATO have not given the response, Moscow was looking for Sergei Lavrov, said that there is still a possibility for a peaceful resolution. In your opinion, is there still a chance to reach an agreement with our partners on key issues that cause our concern? Or is it just an attempt to drag us into an endless negotiation process that has no logical conclusion?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: VLADIMIR PUTIN, Russian President of the United States of America, Mr. President, you have said more than once, and I have said it, and other representatives of Russia, that we warn against endless discussions on issues that need to be resolved today. But still, as head of the foreign ministry, I must say that there is always a chance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: All right, for more on this, let's go straight over to Moscow now, where we can speak to our Russia analyst Galina Polonskaya.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Galina, we just heard there Sergei Lavrov telling President Putin that there's more room for diplomacy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That's a notable change of tone, isn't it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, indeed, it is a notable change of tone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Sergei Lavrov, in a televised part of his meeting with Vladimir Putin, actually said that there was a chance to get to some kind of security agreement with the West.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: At least that's what we understood, that Russia is keen to continue the dialogue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: You heard what Vladimir Putin asked, and the answer was that there is always a chance, and not all of the opportunities are exhausted, and let's seek for more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: So, indeed, what we understand, that Russia wants to discuss more even though Sergei Lavrov underlined once again that the major security concerns of Russia were not answered but there are absolutely some areas that it wants to discuss some confidence building measures limits for missile deployments in Europe and etc and Lavrov underlined that it was something that Russia wanted to discuss in the past but its appeals were ignored and the dialogue continues tomorrow. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is in Moscow. Here he will meet with Vladimir Putin and Sergei Lavrov will meet with the Foreign Minister of Poland who is the OEC chairman in office, Bigniew Rau, and they will first of all discuss the situation in Ukraine and the situation around this mission of the OSCE in Ukraine. And Russia is also very, very worried of what is happening with the mission at this moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Galina, meanwhile, we also understand that there could be the potential for a key vote

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: in the Duma tomorrow. Tell us more about it and crucially what it could mean.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: Well, it is actually very interesting as tomorrow the Russian lawmakers will vote on one of the resolutions that appeals to the Russian president to recognize the self-proclaimed republics in the east of Ukraine. Actually, there are two resolutions. First one will go directly to Vladimir Putin. The second one first will go to the consultations in the foreign and defense ministries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: And the idea initially belongs to the Communist Party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: Its leader, Gennady Zyuganov, in a statement that was published tonight, wrote that this would be Russian firm answer to the U.S. provocations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: And the speaker of Duma in his telegram wrote I quote can you keep continues not to comply with the Minsk agreements at this and this poses threats and risks to the lives of Russian citizens and compatriots living there you should remember that Russia initiated this easy procedure of receiving the Russian passport for those who live in the self-proclaimed republics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: And now there are more than 600,000 of people in those republics that have Russian passports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: So some analysts think that what we are witnessing here is a possible scenario of annexation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: Others say that it is just a pressure from Russia to the West.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Because if it happens, it would be the end to the Minsk agreements, and those agreements are still very important to Russia. Indeed. Galina Polonskaya watching the situation very closely for us from the Russian capital. Galina, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, a member states that border Ukraine said they're preparing for a possible mass influx of refugees in the event of a possible invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And Matthew in the Cube has been looking at the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, to its immediate west, Ukraine is bordered by four European Union member states, Poland, Slovakia, Hungary and Romania.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And in all four of these countries, there are talks or even plans underway in case of a possible influx of Ukrainian refugees in the event of a conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban said over the weekend that a Russian invasion of Ukraine could lead to tens of thousands of people fleeing across the border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now, Poland is the largest of the EU countries that borders Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And there also, the Interior Minister has said that they are prepared for various situations. Poland for now is keeping its diplomatic missions on the ground in Kiev in the case that they are needed to facilitate a large-scale exit of Ukrainian nationals. But they are also making plans at home and that means asking a number of local mayors or authorities to give them details about what accommodation facilities they have available in the event of large-scale arrivals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This could include things like hostels or even sports venues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But at the same time the Polish government has reiterated its hope that a worst-case scenario could be avoided.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now of course it's worth noting that it was not so recently that Poland itself had an image for being anti-refugee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That was when thousands of people, mainly from the Middle East, arrived at the country's border with the Belarus, trying to enter the European Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: In contrast, it's worth noting that Poland has in the past allowed a number of economic migrants from Ukraine to enter the country, as it did during Russia's last incursion in 2014.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: enter the country, as it did during Russia's last incursion in 2014. Now again, they are making the same sort of plans. And indeed, Helena, a number of other EU countries are doing the same, including Slovakia, where the defence minister there has said that the current situation is the most dangerous that Europe as a continent has faced since the Second World War. Matthew, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now, at least seven people have died after an explosion at a building in the south of France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Two children, including a newborn baby, were among the victims.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Twenty-five people had to be evacuated from the building in the town of Saint-Laurent-de-les-Salinques, about 150 kilometres from Montpellier.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Firefighters are continuing to search for victims.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: An investigation into what happened in the fire has been launched.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, the EU has long struggled to find a joint response from all 27 members when it comes to dealing with refugee and migrant arrivals into the bloc. And within the last few months, the thousands of people stuck in freezing temperatures without shelter on the Poland-Belarus border brought the issue back under the spotlight. But just how important is the issue to the citizens of the European Union? Pedro Sacadora went to the Conference on the Future of Europe to find out. A joint migration policy and common facilities for migrants arriving at the EU's borders. Just some of the recommendations coming out of this weekend's Conference on the Future of Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Maastricht was the latest stop in a series of citizen debates hearing the voices of Europeans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A chance for 23-year-old Laura Cinquini from Frontline Italy to have her say on issues like migration.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: I would love to see things change in Italy in terms of the political and media approach to migration.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: I think people talk about migration in the wrong way, without having the precise figures, without having the proper terms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I just would like the way people are informed to change as well, and the way people when they arrive in Europe are hosted, that should change.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: I'd like to see a stronger, more common European policy. It should be much more organised.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Other recommendations include less reliance on oil and gas imports, a topic that has been fuelling tensions within the EU. Just like security, the idea of creating an EU army floated around but has failed to get the green light.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For Guy Verhofstadt, one of the conference's co-chairs, important seeds are being sown for Europe's future.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So the recommendations is not the end of the story. The recommendation of the citizens is the basis for a proposal of reforms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: What we expect, what I expect from this conference is that the fact that the citizens are present and are participating in the decision-making process will create such a pressure on the stakeholders of the European Union, Commission, Parliament, Council, that they cannot longer ignore it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: From Maastricht, the conference travels to Ireland later this month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A chance for more Europeans to bring fresh ideas on digital transformation, social justice, education and jobs. It was here in Maastricht that the EU was shaped three decades ago, but today it is at the heart of conversations about its future. From here citizen panel debates will wrap up in Dublin with all the recommendations going in front of the European Parliament next month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Pedro Sacadura, Euronews, Maastricht.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A court says that exceptional circumstances in the doping case of 15 year old Russian figure skater Kamila Velieva mean that she will be allowed to compete in the Beijing Winter Olympics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now the Court of Arbitration for Sport said that Valieva's age and the timing of her failed test results justify the decision not to suspend her from future events.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The Russian skating star tested positive for a banned substance in December, details of which failed to surface until last week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now cleared, Valieva will perform in Tuesday's individual event where she remains the firm favourite in the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Anti-doping agencies say that they are disappointed with the outcome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Joining me now for the very latest from the Winter Olympics is sports reporter Michael Kern.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Michael, good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: What's the reaction been in Beijing to the news of this decision?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: It's not been great. I've seen one headline which says this is the final nail in the coffin for these farcical winter Olympics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: American former Olympic champion Tara Lipinski said that Valiéva's age should not be a factor in the decision and called her reinstatement a permanent scar on the sport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Ashley Wagner and Johnny Weir, they voiced their outrage as well with the decision.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And of course, we have to remember that Russia are serving a four-year ban from competing at the Games under their own flag over widespread doping.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Of course, all the athletes for Russia are competing under the flag of the Russian Olympic Committee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Obviously, the IOC and WADA, they're not all happy with this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And I think you've said something very interesting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The ruling stated that obviously there's issues with the timing and notification of the results.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: So effectively what Cass is saying is that, yes, it's a failed test, but this came six weeks before the Games, and that's six weeks after she gave her sample.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: So that's played a part in the decision because it's not a test that's happened during the Games.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: So this is going to rumble on for a very long time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I can imagine it will because then on top of this, we've got the fact that Camilla goes into Tuesday's individual event as the hot favourite.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: What happens if she does win?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Well, this is where it gets interesting, because the court didn't rule either on whether Valiéva could keep her gold that she won last week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Now, after the decision by Cass, the Olympic Committee announced that while Valiéva will be allowed to take part in the women's individual figure skating competition, there's going to be no medal ceremony if she is among the prize winners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: If she wins a medal, there's no guarantees that she wouldn't be stripped of it at a later date because, of course, there'll be anti-doping that's happening during this Games as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: So there's a long and lengthy process in this as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: But in the short time she competes, but issues like whether she's taken up her right to ask her B sample to be tested are all part of this anti-doping process, which still remain unresolved.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So yeah, there's a massive kind of cloud over this. There'll also be a wider investigation also into her entourage to find out how a child came to fail a drugs test in the first place. So plenty of questions still need answering. Absolutely. Moving on then, the French ice skating duo Papadakis and Cisagon, they were determined not to have, I think, ice skating completely overshadowed by all this controversy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Talk us through just how impressive they were.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: They were amazing. They won gold with a world record score of 226.98. They beat their previous world record of 226.61, which they set in 2019. And also, it was a lovely bit of redemption for them as well, because at the last games, they missed out on gold by just one point, and their routine was hampered by a wardrobe malfunction as well. But this performance, it was virtually flawless. Everyone was on their feet. Athletes, coaches gave them a massive standing ovation. So they certainly didn't let their day be overshadowed by everything that's gone on in the rest of the games.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Absolutely not. Some great stuff there. Michael Kern bringing us up to date. Thank you, Michael.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, it was a dream come true for fans of the Los Angeles Rams as their team claimed victory over the Cincinnati Bengals on Sunday. It's only the second time that the Rams have won the Super Bowl and they did it on home soil, as Mark Armstrong reports. The SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, California, venue for this year's Super Bowl and home of the winning side, the Los Angeles Rams. But victory over the Cincinnati Bengals came late with just under a minute and a half left on the clock when Cooper Cupp scored his second touchdown to give the Rams their second NFL title.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: It feels great.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Just so happy to be able to celebrate this with such great teammates and my family, people that mean the most to me and just so proud of this group. It's a special feeling.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: You know, you got to be relentless, man. It's about, you want something bad enough, you got to go get it. You know, it was right in front of us. We had the lead.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: You know, it was put on the defensive shoulders, you know, to make the big stop, to help us be world champions. So you won't want it another way.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The final score, 23-20 to the Rams Rams who first won the title back in 2000.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: From canals to parks couples across Europe are meeting up to celebrate the day of love together and what better way to spend Valentine's Day than in some of the continent's most romantic cities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Anka Ula reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Valentine's Day than in some of the continent's most romantic cities. Anka Uhler reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Love is in the air across Europe this Valentine's Day.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In Vienna, often considered Europe's most romantic city, lovers made the most of the good weather to enjoy the city's parks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And those with the sweet tooth are in luck.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Vienna's options for sweet treats are seemingly endless, with cakes short of warm even the iciest of hearts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The city of Vienna is particularly interesting because we live with our sweets and confectionery and our word famous for it. People give away hearts for Valentine's Day. You can write I love you on top. Venice's famous canals take couples on a traditional romantic journey.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: And chocolate shops in the city offer sugary delights that showcase Venetian craftsmanship.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The most precious chocolate creation is the one with the gold leaf, because it's produced by a batturo, which in Venice is an ancient craft that produces these very thin gold leaves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: By beating them with a small hammer, he is able to make these leaves that are edible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile in London, Valentine's Day got off to a roaring start.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: A pair of lions at the London Zoo were given giant cinnamon-scented red hearts to put them in the mood.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And we leave you now with a no comment from Singapore, where fighter jets are taking to the skies for Asia's biggest air show.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Thanks for watching Euronews Tonight. Now! The Jupiter with Drew Ross!
